### Coresidence Rate

$$\text{Coresidence Rate}=\frac{\text{Children living with their parents}}{\text{Total of Children}}$$

### Labor Force Participation & Ocupattion Rate 

$$\text{Labor Force Participation Rate}=\frac{Employed + Unemployed}{\text{Working age population}}$$

![](archivos/Tesis/Participacion_laboral/year_age_part_lab_g.gif){width=60%}

![](archivos/Tesis/Participacion_laboral/inc_age_part_lab_g.gif){width=70%}


$$\text{Ocupation Rate}=\frac{Employed}{\text{Working age population}}$$

![](archivos/Tesis/Participacion_laboral/year_age_ocup_g.gif){width=60%}

![](archivos/Tesis/Participacion_laboral/inc_age_ocup_g.gif){width=70%}


### Intergenerational Elasticity 
$$y_s=\text{Children's income}$$
$$y_f=\text{Father's income (it could be with the mother, but there would be greater bias due to labor participation)}$$
$$X=\text{Control Variables}$$

$$y_s=\beta_0+\underbrace{\beta_1}_{\text{Intergenerational Elasticity}} y_f+\beta_2X+u_i$$
The closer the beta is to 0, the greater the social mobility.
